      "timestamp": "[00:00-00:13]",
      "transcript": "and they would be acting on endogenous pathways um that are already available and it's really hard to kind of um target them specifically to study only the microbially derived population. Um yeah.",

    {
      "speaker": "Xin Zhang, UIUC Biochemistry",
      "timestamp": "[00:13-00:21]",
      "transcript": "in other words, we don't in other words, we don't really know whether that molecule is made by the microbial or made by the neuron system?",
      "speaking duration": 8,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 0,
      "smile_other": 0,

      "hand_gesture": "Open Palms",

    {
      "speaker": "Jill Barone-Haber, UCSD",
      "timestamp": "[00:21-01:13]",
      "transcript": "Uh there's both. So um one example is we've done some work on serotonin and so some microbes can make serotonin de novo and then also microbes can stimulate the host to make serotonin. And that could you know, that gets into the bloodstream and it could either diffuse, you know, and you know, go to other organ systems or it even could act locally on vagal neurons, which all have serotonin receptors. And so I think it's just complicated by the fact that all of these pathways are co-occurring at the same time that you have neuronal acting going on at the same time as diffusion of serotonin and other serotonin related derivatives um and it's kind of difficult to account for the complexity of these happening in tandem.",
      "speaking duration": 52,
      "nods_others": 0,
      "smile_self": 33,
      "smile_other": 0,
      "distracted_others": 0,
      "hand_gesture": "None",

      "screenshare_content": "None"
    },
    {
      "speaker": "Jeff Brian Harmanis, Caltech",
      "timestamp": "[01:13-02:00]",
      "transcript": "And if you think about, you know, all the different ways to transmit that signal, you know, immune cells have serotonin receptors, right? And so you know, and you have most of our immune cells are in our gut and and some circulate out. And so you know, I think just thinking about I I've you know, I'm a big fan of identifying I think molecules give you handles into biological processes, right? And so once you have a molecule, I think you can start asking these types of questions, right? I think you know, you know, so again, that's maybe a product of my training. But um, I think, you know, starting with those molecules, identifying the ones that are active and then looking for those targets and look for those mechanisms, you know, makes you know, makes sense to me. What about from the brain to the gut?",

      "speaker": "Jeff Miller-Goree, A.C. Davis",
      "timestamp": "[02:00-02:11]",
      "transcript": "I think that's been like less studied, right? I think technically it's just easier to do things in the gut and see see what happens to the brain, right? Or or or or behavior or some physiological outcome.",

      "nods_others": 0,

      "timestamp": "[02:11-02:34]",
      "transcript": "But you know, to my knowledge, very little has been done in looking at at brain to gut communications, right? In fact, I'm quite ignorant about about that whether or not there's even a body of of of literature out there. I don't know if if folks have have specific examples or or thoughts about what do we know and more importantly, what don't we know about brain to gut signal?",

      "transcript": "Oh, I was just going to say that to my knowledge, I think there isn't much literature on manipulating the brain to understand the nervous system or the the gut. So I think it would be really interesting to study whether or not those types of intervention can impact the the gut and and something that's that just came to my mind right now is something like transcranial magnetic stimulation um that's commonly used as treatment for depressive disorders and other um psychiatric illnesses that could be really interesting to see how that changes kind of enteric or or gut functioning.",
